Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support for IEEE Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS 2011)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: This award will help to support student attendance at the 52nd IEEE Annual Symposium on the Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS) in Palm Springs, California, on October 22 through October 25, 2011, as well as to support attendance by some qualified postdoctoral fellows who do not have other sources of travel funding. FOCS and its sister conference, the ACM STOC meeting, are the premier broad-based conferences on the Theory of Computing. FOCS has a record of strongly encouraging participation by students, for whom the conference serves as a valuable educational experience, both for the technical content of the talks and for the opportunities for networking that it provides. In recent years, the annual FOCS conference has been attended by eighty to one hundred students who have comprised more than a third of all attendees. This award will provide partial support to twenty or more students, covering shared hotel rooms and travel. (Student registration will be supported by other means.)

POR.DRECONTENT:
FOCS 2011, the 52nd Annual IEEE Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science, brought together roughly 250 researchers from around the world to learn about the latest developments in theoretical computer science.  In addition to the 84 research papers selected for presentation (and publication in the FOCS 2011 conference proceedings), there were three well-attended tutorials on differential privacy, environmentally aware computing, and on fully homomorphic encryption that were aimed at a broad theoretical computer science audience.  The IEEE Edmund R. Piore Award, the top award given by the IEEE in all of
computer science, was given at the conference and accompanied by an award lecture by the winner.

Conference attendance for FOCS 2011 included 84 students and a significant number of postdoctoral fellows.  Of these, 19 students and two post-doctoral fellows were supported by this award (including one student whose support was also supported by carry-over of funds from a separate grant for FOCS 2010).  E-mail requests for travel support for FOCS 2011 were widely solicited prior to the conference and coordinated according to the procedures on the travel support portion of the FOCS 2011 conference web page:  http://www.cs.ucr.edu/~marek/FOCS11/Student_Support/travel-support.html.  Commitments for the travel award were made several weeks in advance of the conference to enable those supported to register early at lower rates.  (Registration fees for students among those supported by this travel grant were covered by a separate amount of one-time support that the IEEE TCMF was able to secure.)   As per the conditions of the grant, travel awards were made for US institutions only.

Participation in conferences such as FOCS is one important component in the training and development of graduate students (and postdoctoral fellows) in the broad area of theoretical computer science. The student travel support program provided stipends that enabled a larger number of students and postdoctoral fellows to attend FOCS and benefit from the training and development opportunities that it offered. The main contribution of this grant is toward the training and development of the 19 theoretical computer science graduate students and two postdoctoral fellows who attended the FOCS 2011 conference through this travel support program.   Attendance at conferences is not only very important for Phd Students and postdoctoral fellows to learn about new research ideas, it gives them an understanding of the social context of the field and helps develop them as productive and independent individuals who will be the research leaders of tomorrow.
